name: American Literature and Culture BA
overview: Students are expected to meet with the undergraduate counselors and undergraduate faculty adviser to plan and follow a course of study that incorporates their interests and goals with the fulfillment of requirements for thedegree.

sections.title: Capstone Program
sections.description: The American Literature and Culture major is a designated capstone program. Students have the option of completing a capstone seminar or other culminating work that enables them to use knowledge and skills acquired through previous coursework to engage, under the guidance of a faculty member, in literary research or other creative projects that result in a final paper or other product.

sections.title: Learning Outcomes
sections.description:
1. Proficiency in a broad knowledge/skill set including research methods, critical thinking, and analytical writing.
2. Familiarity with basic project material including data from multiple sources.
3. Familiarity with relevant scholarly and current debates in the field.
4. Conception and execution of an independent project.
5. Demonstrated seminar or workshop skills.
6. Demonstrated oral and written communication skills.
7. Demonstrated defense-of-scholarship skills.

sections.title: Entry to the Major
sections.description:
Transfer applicants to the American Literature and Culture major with 90 or more units must complete the following introductory courses prior to admission to UCLA: one English composition course, one English critical reading and writing course, and either (1) level five or equivalent in any one foreign language or (2) level three or equivalent in one foreign language and two additional courses in foreign language or literature in translation.

Refer to the UCLA transfer admission guide for up-to-date information regarding transfer selection for admission.

sections.title: Preparation for the Major
sections.description: Complete four courses and a foreign language requirement as follows. English Composition 3 is requisite to any English 4 series course.

requirements.title: Foreign Language
requirements.description: Complete one of the following two options.

options.title: Option 1
options.description: Level five or equivalent in any one foreign language.

options.title: Option 2
options.description: Level three or equivalent in one foreign language and two additional courses in foreign language or literature in translation.

sections.title: The Major
sections.description: Complete 10 4- or 5-unit upper-division courses as follows:

requirements.title: American Literature English Courses
requirements.description: Select seven American literature English courses from the three areas below. Distribution Requirements: At least two courses must be selected from each of the three areas. Additionally, at least two courses must be in the time period before 1848 and two in the time period after 1848.

options.title: Origins—Beginnings, Events, and Trajectories
options.description: Studying the Making of America in Its Myriad Beginnings and Manifestations. Select at least two from this area. Note: Courses ENGL M101B, 106, 123, 131, 139, 169 are only applicable when treating American topics.

options.title: Identities: Places, Communities, and Environments
options.description: Studying People, Collectives and Movements across the Diverse Geographies of the Americas. Select at least two from this area. Note: Courses ENGL M101B, M101C, M101D, M103, M107A, M107B, 108, 109, 118E, M118F, 119, 119XP, M126, 132, 133, 134, 139 are only applicable when treating American topics.

options.title: Media: Aesthetics, Genres, and Technologies
options.description: Select at least two from this area. Note: Courses ENGL 114, 115C, 115D, 115E, M115XP, 116A, 116B, 121, 122, 123, 124, 125, M126, 127, 129, 139, 169, 169R, 179, 179R are only applicable when treating American topics.

requirements.title: Seminar
requirements.description: Select one course from the following list. Note: Courses ENGL 180, 181A, 181B, 182E, 182F, 184, M191D, M191E are only applicable when treating American topics.

requirements.title: American Culture Courses from Other Departments
requirements.description: Complete two courses pertaining to American culture offered by other departments from a list of approved courses for the major. Courses 195 and 195CE are not applicable.

sections.title: Honors Program
sections.description: Students must take one theory course from English 120 through 128 no later than winter quarter of the junior year. In spring quarter of the junior year, students must take course 191H. During fall and winter quarters of the senior year, they take courses 198A and 198B, in which they write a thesis under the direction of a faculty member.

sections.title: Policies
sections.description:
### Preparation for the Major Policies
A grade of C or better is required in each of English Composition 3, English 4W or 4HW or 4WX, 11, and 87. A foreign literature in translation course list is available from the department. Transfer students who have satisfied the College of Letters and Science foreign language requirement at the high-school level through the IGETC program may satisfy the departmental requirement with five foreign literature in translation courses. Courses satisfying the major foreign language requirement may be taken on a Passed/Not Passed (P/NP) grading basis.

### The Major Policies
Each course applied toward requirements for the major must be at least 4 units and be taken for a letter grade.

### Honors Program Policies
**Admission**: The honors program is open to majors with a 3.5 departmental and a 3.25 overall grade-point average (GPA). Students with lower GPAs may petition for admission but must achieve these GPAs before graduation to qualify for honors. Students should apply by winter quarter of the junior year. For application forms and more information, contact the departmental counselor.
**Requirements**: In most cases, courses required for departmental honors are not eligible to fulfill requirements for the American Literature and Culture major. Potential exceptions should be discussed with a departmental counselor in advance. The thesis determines whether the student receives highest honors, honors, or no honors.
